docs.snippet: A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The colonel, Juan Antonio Rodríguez Buratti, was one of nine military and police officers accused of kidnapping and then killing María Claudia García in 1976. Ms. García was the daughter-in-law of the Argentine poet Juan Gelman, who has campaigned so doggedly for justice on her behalf that the case has become an issue in relations between Argentina and Uruguay.

headline.main: Uruguay: Suicide in Notorious Abuse Case
headline.print_headline: URUGUAY: SUICIDE IN NOTORIOUS ABUSE CASE

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-12    Report Urges More Troops And Aid for Western Iraq  An assessment by Col. Peter Devlin, the senior Marine intelligence officer in Anbar Province, Iraq, said the situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Report Urges More Troops And Aid for Western Iraq An assessment by Col. Peter Devlin, the senior Marine intelligence officer in Anbar Province, Iraq, said the situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops there. A1 Accord Reached, Abbas Says The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, said he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas to form a national unity government in an attempt to the end the Palestinians' isolation and the cutoff of Western aid. A1 Iran Closes 4 Publications Iran's press watchdog closed four journals, including a a major reformist newspaper that was shut down indefinitely for refusing to replace its director and publishing a cartoon that was considered insulting to the government, according to a statement by the press monitoring agency. A12 Rice Eases U.S. Stance on Iran Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice left open the possibility that the United States might suspend efforts to impose sanctions against Iran if it suspends uranium enrichment for two months. A12 Snubs for Blair in Lebanon Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain dodged demonstrators and endured a series of diplomatic snubs on his first official visit to Lebanon. Several ministers refused to meet him. A10 Political Rivals Court Uruguay Uruguay has become a main front in the struggle between the United States and Venezuela for dominance in South America. The Bush administration and President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela are trying to undercut each other in an attempt to win over Uruguay's left-wing government. A3 NATIONAL A14-21 Across the Nation, 9/11 Is Remembered From digital signs urging remembrance to elected officials' musing on the demands of guarding against terrorism at home, the many ways of observing 9/11 showed how deep an imprint was made -- not only by the attack, but by the surge of solidarity that followed. A18 President Bush used the fifth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks to assert that the United States is engaged in ''a struggle for civilization'' and sought to invoke a sense of national purpose in making his case anew for seeing through the war in Iraq. A16 Shuttle Reaches Destination The shuttle Atlantis slid gently into place at its destination, the International Space Station, clearing the way for construction of the station to begin again. A21 Computer Hacking Investigated The California Highway Patrol is investigating outside breaches of a computer system used by aides to Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to store downloaded audio files, a spokesman for the patrol said. A14 Court Rejects Blogger's Appeal In a case closely watched by First Amendment advocates, a federal court panel has rejected an appeal by a freelance journalist and blogger who has refused to appear before a grand jury or turn over video he shot of a violent protest last summer. A14 EDUCATION No Early Admission to Harvard Harvard University will eliminate its early admissions program next year, arguing that such programs put low-income and minority applicants at a disadvantage in the competition to get into selective universities. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-9 Solemn Tributes Mark 5th Anniversary of 9/11 On the fifth anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, thousands gathered at ground zero, at the Pentagon and in a field in Pennsylvania where the hijacked jetliners crashed. They included families and friends of the 2,973 people who died, President Bush and other public officials and countless strangers united by haunting but receding memories. A1 Thousands of workers marched through Lower Manhattan wishing for a routine day at the office, but the memories were too fresh and painful to ignore completely. B1 New York's politicians stopped campaigning on the eve of today's primary elections, solemnly marking 9/11, but their aides were busy mobilizing get-out-the-vote operations, releasing last-minute commercials, and trying to influence media coverage of tonight's results. B3 SCIENCE TIMES F1-10 Washing Away the Guilt Liars, cheats, philanderers and murderers feel a strong urge to wash their hands -- literally -- after a despicable act in an unconscious effort to ease their consciences, according to a new study. F5 Health & Fitness F5 SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6 Cyclists Admit Drug Use Two of Lance Armstrong's eight teammates from the 1999 Tour de France have admitted for the first time that they used the banned endurance-boosting drug EPO in preparing for the race that year, when they helped Armstrong capture the first of his record seven titles. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 Upheaval at Bristol-Myers A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made. C1 Scrutiny of Hewlett Grows Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny over the investigative tactics it used against its own directors, and the board spent a second day trying to find a way out of the crisis. C1 Revived Interest in Univision A consortium of investors led by Mexico's largest media company is considering a $13 billion bid for Univision Communications, executives said. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: President Bush's reality; the fictional path to 9/11; from sacristy to lockup; primary election choices. Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof. docs.snippet: A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: A retired army colonel accused of involvement in a notorious case of human rights abuses has committed suicide, shooting himself after police officers went to his home in Montevideo to advise him he would have to appear in court to face charges. The colonel, Juan Antonio Rodríguez Buratti, was one of nine military and police officers accused of kidnapping and then killing María Claudia García in 1976. Ms. García was the daughter-in-law of the Argentine poet Juan Gelman, who has campaigned so doggedly for justice on her behalf that the case has become an issue in relations between Argentina and Uruguay. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)
docs.abstract: Juan Antonio Rodriguez Buratti, retired Uruguayan army colonel accused of human rights abuses, commits suicide; was about to face charges related to 1976 kidnapping and murder of Maria Claudia Garcia, daughter-in-law of Argentine poet Juan Gelman (S)
